raschdash 0.0.0.9000
  • Reference

Fit a raschdash model

Source: R/rdfit.R
rdfit.Rd

Create an rdfit object from dimensional data.

new_rdfit(
  cohorts,
  groups,
  persons,
  person_groups,
  testlets,
  items,
  item_testlets,
  item_max_scores,
  K = 0,
  obs_group_cohorts,
  obs_groups,
  obs_group_items,
  obs_group_scores,
  obs_person_cohorts,
  obs_persons,
  obs_person_items,
  obs_person_scores,
  ...
)

rdfit(
  data,
  cohort = NULL,
  group,
  person,
  testlet,
  item,
  max_score,
  K = 0,
  obs_score,
  ...
)

Arguments

cohorts

vector of unique cohort identifiers
groups

vector of unique group identifiers
persons, person_groups

vectors of unique person identifiers (persons) and the identifiers of their corresponding groups (person_groups)
testlets

vector of unique testlet identifiers
items, item_testlets, item_max_scores

vectors of unique item identifiers (items) and their corresponding testlets (item_testlets) and maximum scores(max_scores)
K

maximum score of rating-scale items. Defaults to no rating scales.
obs_group_cohorts, obs_groups, obs_group_items, obs_group_scores

for the group-level observations, vectors of the corresponding cohorts (obs_group_cohorts), groups (obs_groups), items (obs_group_items), and observed scores (obs_group_scores)
obs_person_cohorts, obs_persons, obs_person_items, obs_person_scores

for the person-level observations, vectors of the corresponding cohorts (obs_person_cohorts), persons (obs_persons), items (obs_person_items), and observed scores (obs_person_scores)
...

additional parameters passed to rstan::sampling()
data

a data frame with columns for cohort, group, person, testlet, item, maximum possible item score, and observed score. For group-level observations, the person should be NA.
cohort

tidyr::tidyr_tidy_select() cohort column. Defaults to a generic All cohort.
group

tidyr::tidyr_tidy_select() group column
person

tidyr::tidyr_tidy_select() person column
testlet

tidyr::tidyr_tidy_select() testlet column
item

tidyr::tidyr_tidy_select() item column
max_score

tidyr::tidyr_tidy_select() maximum-score column
obs_score

tidyr::tidyr_tidy_select() observed score column

Value

An rdfit object, which has the following attributes.

stanfit

the rstan::stanfit() object for the fitted model. It contains samples of the following parameters.

  • logit-scale parameters

    xi

    group abilities

    eta

    person abilities

    epsilon

    testlet difficulties

    delta

    item difficulties

    tau

    rating-scale threshold offsets from overall item difficulty (if any rating-scale items are present)

    lambda

    standard deviation of person abilities. Used to transform the logit scale to the standard scale.

  • standard-scale parameters

    group_ability

    group abilities

    person_ability

    person abilities

    testlet_difficulty

    testlet difficulties

    item_difficulty

    item difficulties

    thresholds

    rating-scale threshold offsets from overall item difficulty (if any rating-scale items are present)

  • standard-scale parameters under their prior distribution given the posterior distribution of the hyper-parameters

    prior_group_ability

    prior_person_ability

    prior_testlet_difficulty

    prior_item_difficulty

  • posterior predictive distribution

    y_rep

    predicted score for each observed combination of group, person, and item

  • log likelihoods

    log_lik

    log likelihood of observed scores

    log_lik_rep

    log likelihood of predicted scores

loo

a loo::loo() object for stanfit

Details

The rdfit function is intended to be the primary method for users to create rdfit objects. Most R users work with so-called dimensional data in a single data frame. In the case that the data are alread stored in a normalised form, however, the raw new_rdfit constructor will work. Be aware that new_rdfit does not validate whether the data are properly normalised, and Stan will throw rather cryptic error message if they are not.

Functions

  • new_rdfit: Create an rdfit object from normalised data.
